title: World Grand Prix Darts: Cross and Wright exits leave Van Gerwen as lone seed standing
text:
Rob Cross was beaten by Glen Durrant on Wednesday night (Picture: Getty Images)

Michael van Gerwen is the only seeded player left in the World Grand Prix at the quarter-final stage after Rob Cross and Peter Wright crashed out on Wednesday evening.

It has been a tournament full of shocks so far in Dublin, with seven of the eight seeds all beaten in the first two rounds, leaving the world number one as the runaway favourite to win the event for a fifth time.

World number two Cross was edged out 3-2 by debutant Glen Durrant on Wednesday night, while Wright was beaten 3-1 by Dutch star Jermaine Wattimena.

Duzza and Wattimena now meet in the last eight, while the other quarter-finals see MVG take on Mervyn King, Chris Dobey face Ian White and Dave Chisnall play Nathan Aspinall.

Few would have backed that line-up to be taking to the oche on Thursday night, but such is the unpredictable nature of the double-in event in Dublin.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Durrant, who continues his remarkable first year on the PDC circuit, was critical of his own performance in his victory over Cross, but is eyeing an improvement in his quarter-final clash with Wattimena.

‘I wish I could stand here being really happy but there’s something not quite right with the way I’m playing at the moment,’ said the reigning BDO world champion.

‘One thing I don’t lack is bottle and that’s what got me through tonight. I’ve come through a really tough section of the draw without playing well.

‘I know I need to up my game in the next round if I’m to progress and that’s what I’m working towards now.’

Aspinall, Dobey and Durrant are all debutants in the World Grand Prix and will all be playing for a place in the semi-finals on Thursday evening at the Citywest hotel.

UK Open champion Aspinall beat Danny Noppert 3-2 in the last 16, to set up his clash with Chisnall, who comfortably saw off Stephen Bunting 3-0 in the second round.

‘I’m proud, relieved, it was a really, really tough game,’ the Asp told Live Darts after beating Noppert.

‘I felt it was a battle for both of us, I just battled, like Nathan does, and booked my place in the quarters.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘All my family are back at my house in Stockport celebrating my daughter’s second birthday and I can’t be there. I’ve had a lot of emotion today because it’s all new to me, this game, being away from home a lot.

‘Darts means everything to me but not as much as my daughter. Maybe that;s why I struggled for times because I wanted to win so much for her.’

World Grand Prix Quarter-finals Ian White v Chris Dobey

Dave Chisnall v Nathan Aspinall

Michael van Gerwen v Mervyn King

Glen Durrant v Jermaine Wattimena
